content: Hi, I just wanted to ask what y'all are using to search for finite (counter)-examples? There is a plethora of possible tools, and I just wondered whether alg (https://github.com/andrejbauer/alg) could be of any use. It's a program specialized to enumerate finite first-order theories, and specialized for the algebraic theories. I suspect by now you have tools that outperform alg?
We have https://github.com/leanprover-community/plausible. I think though that it's scope is different from alg.

Yes, I think alg would have been useful very early on, but so late in the project I doubt it can really help. It's very easy to make initial experiments with alg (you just type in the axioms and run it), but any kind of specialized tool would outperform it.

Where can I find a list of implications that are conjectured to be false?
In the Austin pairs channel, there is a list of unknown finite implications. The remaining implications in the general case are known to be true for finite models.
The project has an equation explorer in the webpage

The Conjectures.lean file lists a generating set of implications that we believe to be false, but have not yet proved. There are eight additional implications that we have not yet resolved, depicted in this Graphiti.
Have you generated the smallest magmas witnessing non-implications (when that's possible)?
Wait, that's slightly different than what you asked.

These are the smallest examples of a given magma, for witnesses of specific non-implications, we do not necessarily have the smallest. In fact, in some limited cases, we do not know if finite counterexamples exist.

If I understand you correctly, that is what I asked. (I asked: in cases where ¬(EquationX ⇒ EquationY), do you have the smallest magma witnessing this fact?)

I was asking because that might be one thing that alg could help with, as it searches for smallest examples first. Anyhow, interesting stuff, thanks for answering my question.
Andrej Bauer has marked this topic as resolved.

I don't believe we have the witnesses you're talking about. The links I gave are the smallest examples of a given magma, not for a particular refutation. In general, we exhaustively searched 2x2-5x5 magmas, and after that, used various methods that may or may not have generated minimal counterexamples. And as I mentioned, we are not sure that we have generated all of the possible counterexamples yet anyway.

EDIT: 5x5 was not fully explored, 4x4 was.
I see. But that's ok, you're way ahead of what alg can do, it will choke on magmas of size 4, and definitely 5.
